text:
hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with souffle pancakes that's right

I'm gonna show you my technique for
making souffle pancakes which by the way

should not be confused with Japanese
souffle pancakes which while much taller

and visually impressive are not in my
occasionally humble opinion as good a

pancake eating experience
alright I'm trying to eat a pancake and

not a cylinder of sweet and eggy foam
but anyway let's move on from throwing

shade to getting these made but before
we get to the batter let me show you a

nice trick for prepping your berries if
you're gonna top your pancakes with

these which is very much recommended and
what I like to do is actually pour some

maple syrup over my berries and we'll go
ahead and gently mix those with our

spoon and what this is gonna do is give
those berries a beautiful shine and

possibly make for a little better
presentation I mean it's a proven

scientific fact that people love shiny
food so we'll go ahead and give those a

mix and set them aside at which point we
can move on to our souffl√© pancake

batter which we'll begin by separating
two large room-temperature eggs and as

you can see I like to do this by
cracking the egg in my hand and letting

the whites fall between my fingers which
i think is very effective and feels

pretty cool so that's my separation
policy but if you want to use the

shelter shell method go ahead oh and
remember a little bit of the white in

the yolk bowl is okay but we don't want
any of the yolk and the white bowl

otherwise we might have problems
whipping those up and then what we'll do

once those are separated has add some
white sugar to our yolks

and we'll go ahead and whisk that for
about a minute or two until our sugar

dissolves and the mixture takes on this
beautiful pale yellow appearance and

then once that's been accomplished we'll
go ahead and add a little vanilla

extract the pure and the real as well as
a little bit of milk and a little bit of

melted butter and then we'll give that a
quick mix to combine

before sifting in some self-rising flour
and by sifting in I mean just dump it

all in okay I'm not a big sifter and
I've never really had an issue so go

ahead and sift it if you want but I'm
just gonna go ahead and take the whisk

and mix that in and as usual if you
don't have self-rising flour

I'm gonna tell you what to do in the
blog post it's very easy to make

yourself but anyway we'll go ahead and
give that a mix just until that flower

disappears at which point we'll stop and
move on to whipping our egg whites but

before I do that I'm gonna add one
optional ingredient a little pinch of

cream of tartar which helps stabilize
the egg whites which means theoretically

they're gonna whip up bigger and faster
oh and by the way make sure you're using

a clean whisk for this and not that
dirty one you just used for the batter

okay so start with a clean whisk and
preferably your biggest widest one

okay the bigger the whisk the faster
this is gonna go which reminds me

cream of tartar or not this is only
gonna take a couple minutes so

personally I don't think it's worth
dirtying a mixer for so I almost always

do this by hand Plus this is as close to
a workout as I'm gonna get this week and

what we want to do is whip these until
we have fairly stiff peaks okay so right

here I was getting close and those are
what most people would consider soft

peaks so we'll go ahead and give that a
few more seconds until we have peaks

that look like this where you see how
that peak is standing I'm nice and tall

and sharp without flopping over okay
that's what we're going for and then

what we'll do at this point is switch to
a spatula and we'll transfer roughly 1/3

of our whites into our batter which we
will stir and fold in and as you may

know this first edition is just to
lighten the mixture in anticipation for

folding in the rest of the whites so we
don't need to be super gentle with this

first edition but of course on the other
hand you do want to use a relatively

light touch okay the less air we knock
out the better and then once we've

lighten that mixture with the first
third of the whites we will go ahead and

transfer the rest in at which point
we'll fold those in but much more

carefully are using nice long slow
movements we are scraping that spatula

along the bottom bringing that batter up
over the top as we occasionally rotate

the bowl oh and I should mention I'm
doing a very basic version here okay if

you wanted to sneak in a little bit of
flavoring into your batter like some

almond extract or maybe some freshly
grated lemon zest be my guest

I mean you are after all the one-man
Wolf Pack of your extra-light flapjack

so go ahead and flavor these as you see
fit

but anyway we'll go ahead and carefully
and thoughtfully folding our egg whites

as shown at which point we should have a
beautiful super light airy batter and

then once that's done we can switch to a
scooper or spoon and we'll head to the

stove where we're gonna cook these up in
a lightly buttered non-stick pan set

over between medium low and medium heat
in case you're wondering the reason I'm

using such a small pan and totally
inappropriately crowding these is

because while the first side cooks we
really want to cover them and I simply

don't have a cover that fits my big
nonstick so as you can see I am really

pushing it here with the spacing
although since I'm doing it wrong

I might as well show you a little tip if
you give these like a minute to set you

can actually sort of separate them with
the edge of a spatula which is probably

recommended so they're easier to turn
but anyway once our batter has been

placed in what we'll do is go ahead and
cover these and cook them for about

three minutes or so or until we see
bubbles popping up through the top and

they start to dry out a little bit
around the edges and once that happens

we'll go ahead and uncover them and we
will give them a flip which as you can

see is extremely challenging when
they're this close together but you know

what I got it done and that's because I
did it with confidence and did not let

those pancakes sense any fear
oh yes food can sense fear and then

you're gonna have issues and the reason
we're keeping our heat kind of on the

low end is because these do take a few
minutes to cook through and if our pan

gets too hot we're gonna go from golden
brown to golden black so somewhere

between medium low and medium should be
perfect and that's it once successfully

flipped we'll give that second side
another two or three minutes at which

point we'll pull them from the heat and
get them ready to eat which means

transferring those on to a nice warm
plate all right only a crazy person

would put hot pancakes on a cold plate
and if I remember in the blog post I

will tell you my favorite ways to warm
those up and then once played it we'll

go ahead and spoon over our shiny
berries along with that now slightly

berry infused maple syrup which I really
wanted to use more of but I was trying

to be good plus we're gonna get all that
beautiful juicy sweetness from the

berries
and that's it I finished up with a

little bit of powdered sugar which is
completely unnecessary although if you

are gonna take pictures it does look
kind of nice and that's it what we're

calling souffle pancakes are done so let
me go ahead and grab a fork and dig in

and what we're attempting to do with
this technique is to create the lightest

airiest most delicate pancake possible
that still feels and tastes like a

pancake
and I'm very happy to report that's

exactly what we have here okay these
things really are feather-light yet you

still feel like you're eating a good
old-fashioned pancake and not some tall

foamy cylinder that's reminiscent of a
pancake alright there's nothing wrong

with a steam room but it's just not the
same thing as a shower and yes that

analogy was as bad as these pancakes
were good and again as you can hopefully

see from this shot just because we
didn't use a mold and these are not

super high doesn't mean they're not
everybody's Aryan light so I really do

think with this approach we have the
best of both worlds

so whether you're gonna do these for a
fancy Easter or Mother's Day brunch or

just some weeknight when you feel like
doing breakfast for dinner I really do

hope you give these a try soon so head
over to food wishes comm for all the

ingredient amounts of more info as usual
and as always enjoy
you
you
